Ye scenes of contentment and glee,</br>Where peace and pure innocence dwell;</br>Ye musical woodlands of Dee,</br>I now bid these woodlands farewel.
How oft, in the sweet birchen bow'r,</br>Secure from the world's rude alarms,</br>Have I sat with retirement — mild pow'r!</br>And tasted her delicate charms!
How oft have I hied to the hill,</br>On Fancy's adventurous wing;</br>Or mus'd by the side of the rill,</br>Nor envy'd or noble or king!
Unfetter'd by fashion or mode,</br>Pure nature held absolute sway,</br>In the chearful and peaceful abode,</br>Where love and sweet liberty stray.
I priz'd, o'er the juice of the vine,</br>Yon fountain of heav'n-gifted pow'r;</br>Where health has erected her shrine—</br>Where votaries grateful adore.
Ye shepherds who frolic and toy</br>On the flow'ry, green margins of Dee,</br>Rejoice in the bliss you enjoy,</br>From pride and ambition set free.
When I think on the charms of the plain,</br>What raptures my bosom shall soothe!—</br>When I think on each nymph and each swain,</br>That I lov'd in my childhood and youth!
But chiefly my heart ye must warm,</br>Ye pride of the pastoral throng!</br>Ye souls whom the beauties can charm</br>Of harmony, nature and song!
That day, when I dare to decry</br>The pleasure such beauties inspire,</br>May the Muse her sweet solace deny,</br>And untune both my tongue and my lyre.
Enrapt with thy converse refin'd,</br>O Kn—l—s!  how I pitied the croud—</br>To folly and fashion resign'd</br>The thoughtless, the pert, and the proud!
The endearments of no foreign clime</br>Shall estrange the lov'd scene of my youth,</br>The nurse of instruction sublime—</br>Of virtue, sincerity, truth.
Farewel, ye dear nymphs and ye swains!</br>Be innocent, happy and free:—</br>Farewel, my dear native green plains,</br>The rural retirements of Dee!</br>
